comments.commentBody: Oops, sorry, buggy post, I meant to write "A few years ago, Android was buggier than iOS."

Like many people, I often wonder what I can do in the fact of natural disasters, the latest being the Ebola outbreak. I have been involved in various efforts to respond to dire situations both here and in other parts of the world, starting with Hurricane Huge in 1989 and continuing with the civil war in Somalia in the '90s, etc. (All very modest efforts.) The biggest problem is that the response is always too slow. It takes too long to wake up the world to a problem, get the needed goods and personnel into the affected area and to make a significant difference. All too frequently, when the most could be accomplished, resources are lacking.

This is the case now, by all appearances, with Ebola in west Africa. It has taken far too long for the wealthy world to wake up to the seriousness of the problem in the deprived world. Once awakened, it has taken too long to respond. Those individual or small groups that have responded, like those who sent two container loads of medical supplies to Liberia have been met with official resistance from the local govt., blocking the supplies at the shipping terminal, according to reports.

Where is leadership? Where is someone with the authority and the audacity to get things done? After the earthquake in Haiti in 2010, people were having limbs removed with ordinary home saws, yet across the water in Jamaica, there were surgical supplies that went nowhere. Why do we have to keep repeating these same sad stories?

http://terryreport.com

A smarter terrorist would have started a fire, or looked for ways to cause an explosion (via natural gas pipeline) or major accident (train derailing, for instance). Most of these types, however, are not smart.

One of the highest-body-count incidents in the United States involved an idiot drunk with some gasoline. No shots involved, nor even planning -- he set a fire at the building his ex-girlfriend worked and went home to sleep off the booze. Killed 87 people... which, for instance, is even more than Brevik killed despite the latter using both bomb and gun.
Always good to see basic laws of physics interjected into human body-weight conversation...

If it were as simply as telling people to "eat less and exercise more," then there would be no obesity problem. Our bodies are not bomb calorimeters, different types and qualities of foods have different effects on the body, independent of calories, and not everything that we eat is even used for "energy."

Finally, thermodynamics does not specify causation. Hunger and lethargy can be effects just as easily as they can be causes.

Sorry. I've been a low processed food vegan and have both gained and lost weight on that diet. I have two very unsexy rules which are thermodynamically guaranteed to work: 1) eat less 2) exercise more.

The big problem is that people believe the lies and are too lazy to seek out the truth. Massachusetts ranks in the top five states with any metric that measures quality of life issues including #1 in public education, life expectancy, infant mortality, maternal death rates, #3 per capita income, #49 in gun deaths, #49 in road fatalities, #2 in grade A hospital care, etc. Yet the average voter believes that our state is heading in the wrong direction. The only direction we have to go in is down, yet we are on the cusp of electing a republican back into office as governor because the people are too lazy to do a bit of research for themselves. I don't believe there is any way to fix this willful ignorance and childish petulance. I just hope the state and country can survive until we come to our collective senses. However I'm not very optimistic.

If woman’s issues were the centerpiece of the election the Democrats would be winning . But the party of the hypocrites is predicted to take the Senate turn back the clock.

Either women are not interested in women’s issues, e.g., the right to control their own reproductive decisions, their health care including contraception and workplace pay equality, etc., or they do not believe that voting will make any difference and no matter how they vote the entrenched right wing oligarchy which has replaced our democratically elected government with the assistance of the Sup Ct., will see to it that woman remain subservient and powerless.

For years the message of the GOP is that government is the enemy and people should be disgusted with government. Thus we have a govt. rigged economy where to the benefits flow to the people on top and the masses are left far behind. There are govt. shutdowns, threats to crash the world economy by defaulting on our debts, paralyzing government, firing hundreds of thousands of unionized govt. workers, and actively impeding the recovery and condemning Obama for doing whatever he does, even it they previously advocated it. No governing and politics all the time.

No wonder people are apathetic, plus voter suppression and election fraud. And it is going to get worse if the majority do not become enraged and march or crawl to the polls and for just spite show the GOP that their billionaire oligarchs haven’t killed democracy just yet.

This isn't just about sports, academics, and money.  There's clearly a racial aspect to a fraud perpetrated within the Afro-American Studies department.  I have taught in a North Carolina high school outside the Research Triangle.   Separation of the races is alive and well, even if under one roof.  Remedying the situation here without examining the racial divide is simply not possible.  But sweeping the issue under the rug makes life easier for everyone involved.
Take a trip from UNC to Fort Bragg and watch young men and women marching in full gear through and maneuvering through a swamp.  You can really be proud of them.
Tom - If you are no longer at that university, why not name it?  Such fear just perpetuates the corrupt system...
Free rides for Jocks no longer happening. Obviously UNC is the tip of the iceberg.

"Hard to fathom?" When even the players talked about the classes?

UNC is still covering up.

The whistleblower tutor reported this years ago - and UNC harrassed her non-stop for years until she recently quit. Administrators knew. Coaches knew, as the tutor reported. Remember, this investigator was HIRED by UNC. Not much independence there.
Rashad McCants: "See?  I told you."

A "Land Economy" class?  Easy to sneer, but might its coverage include location theory?  Productivity theory? Theories of economic rents?  Or, more broadly, theories of Income distribution?  Might it discuss inheritance and incentives? The evolution of feudalism? I can very easily imagine a very challenging course with such a title, just as I can imagine a course in beekeeping and honey production in a College of Agriculture.  Send me a copy of the course syllabus for "Land Economy" after you have read it carefully and exposed its fraudulence. Haven't done that?  And you feel entitled to disparage?  Okay. I guess.
Let's not even ask why the majority of Americans rowing for the university while studying at Cambridge University (England) are enrolled on a 'Land Economy' course...

"Ms. Boxill is currently the director of the university’s Parr Center for Ethics." Do people at UNC even know what the word means?
But I cannot be too sanctimonious. At the University of Oklahoma, where I teach, I know that similar, though perhaps not as egregious, programs exist. A whole degree program (Multidisciplinary Studies) attracted huge numbers of students partly to help athletes, but mostly to drive up the school's graduation rate. This goes well beyond the misplaced reverence of a few faculty in the service of athletics. It has as much to do with university administrators who massage any and all programs to make their institution look better than it actually is.
Where there is college football / basketball / hockey et al., there are frauds like this one.  You're right: the practice is ubiquitous.
Cheating pays. The consequences imposed by the NCAA are always minimal.
When the director of UNC's Center for Ethics (Jan Boxill) doesn't behave ethically, how can one expect its student-athletes to behave any better?

There was a Book "Dexter" .. about a Washington Redskins player who came from Oklahoma State.. who was functionally illiterate.. It is common for Athletic Departments to have courses in Parks and Recreation management, coaching methods and such that are NOT too challenging.. After all one must practice for Saturday's Game.. that is really important to thousands of Alumni..
Say, didn't they make a movie about this?  "Accepted" - the film about South Harmon Institute of Technology, starring Jonah Hill and Justin Long.  UNC - just like in the movies!
Umm, some of the white athletes don't belong in college, either.

Every team has 'personalities' and Pence and Lincecum really aren't that weird or anomalous. Brian Wilson? That guy is eccentric. Lincecum and Pence are simply hardworking guys with unusual looks.

This is just another piece by a conservative east coast writer who sees all west coast people as crazy liberals.

I'm not sure you have that quotation exactly right. Here's how it appeared in print at the time: "It wasn't often, but...we're boys, boys fight, boys wrestle boys. It was usually good humored wrestling, but a few times, of course, it did get physical and...some of my closest friends have seen him hit me before."

I think it's important to stay as close to the truth as possible, especially when discussing something like domestic violence.

Our thoughts and our prayers are with you Canada. Please extend our deepest condolences to the family of the young soldier who died while standing honor guard before the monument to those who fell that you may be free.
He didn't deserve this, no one does. In his name and for his sake stay strong and know that such evil men will never win.

Next time there are shooters killing people in your own neighborhood or in the Texas state capitol building, I doubt you will be so blase' about it or as unsympathetic. Why are you downplaying this incident - are you afraid guns will get a bad reputation?

Ebola is NOT one of the most infections diseases, can't be transmitted by air. Witness that the girlfriend of Eric Duncan, the fellow who died in Dallas, had him living with her even when he was showing signs of the illness but never contracted the disease. The 2 nurses who did contract it were handling his bodily fluids meaning vomit, urine, blood, feces - not sweat or breath. Think of all the health workers who have NOT contracted it in the U.S. and elsewhere.

It is interesting to find that robots could be used to protect people from diseases. Ebola is one of the most infectious and deadly diseases that we want to shun away from it. Although family members of Ebola patients may face cultural obstacles in accepting robots as replacements for physical meetings, I think robots would be helpful to both patients and family members. Ebola is transmitted by physical contacts with patients' bodily fluids, which, I assume, include sweat and breath. Robots employed to perform decontamination tasks or screen family members to patients will certainly lessen the possibilities of casualties.

The Globalist Corporations worshiped by Republican "investors" depend on Corporate Law and a Justice System, aircraft-carriers to protect their precious container ships, US military to protect their "assets" like Oil, and other Treaties, use of highways and other infrastructures which has been built by public taxes and dozens of other benefits that the US financial systems provide for these multinational Corporations that ordinary citizen would not be about to use. Yet, they do every conceivable trick in the accounting books to dodge paying taxes, and when that is not enough GOP proposes a more TAX CUT for the 1%, that includes Multinational Corporations.
They just don't want to pay their Share – they believe 99% should pay the Taxes (Government expanders) AND the 1% enjoy the benefits of the government provided security and infrastructures which has been financed and paid for by taxes.

The clueless Republicans never understand where our economy stands. They continue planning to push spending cuts when aggregate demands continue to be in shortage in spite of the declining interest rates. They will further harm our economic growth as they did with various austerity measures after 2008.
What will happen more certainly is that the US economy will enter into Japan-like deflation without recovery of housing market. The corporate profits will not continue to increase and the stock markets will resume collapse of 2008.
Once these things happen, everybody including top 1% will financially suffer.
Good luck, and godspeed to them in this magnificent effort.
